TopicTitle: You Know You've Kerballed Too Much When...

Articles.Content:
You know you've kerballed too much when you start accidentally applying rocket science to everyday life in ways that don't really work. When you're thinking in terms of rockets, it can sometimes get challenging to stop!

Tell us how you tell when you've given KSP a bit more attention than you originally planned!

I'll start:

You know you've kerballed too much when you want to get on the roof of a building and think "I know, I need a jet-powered wall car!"

You know you kerballed too much when you try to time warp on other games.

And when you think about if we have enough delta v to move this tank to the capture zone.
When you try to initiate docking maneuvers with a revolving door and end up getting pinched.
You know you've kerballed too much when you see a risky NASA mission and, for a second, think "why don't they just quicksave?"
You know you kerbaled too much when you pressthe dot and comma keys to warp
When during a lecture, you think "Didn't recent updates break this system?"
You know you've Kerballed too much when you look at planes and see the center of lift, mass and thrust.
You know you have Kerballed too much when you look at this, and imagine it's flying to Mars right now x-]
You know you've kerballed too much when you're the smartest kid in the physics class just because of playing a video game.

And when you think about if we have enough delta v to move this tank to the capture zone.

... and you always end up getting late to everything. I'm looking at you, Matilda.
When you try to timewarp in real life. Ex: trying to timewarp while driving home (has happened to me before.)

.... When you you try to use the arrow keys to rotate your view of a picture/video (I know everyone here has done that)

... When something falls over and you say it needed more struts

... When you can't lift something and you think "Moar boosters!"
When you say Mun instead of Moon and look for Minmus in the sky.
When you spend a nonzero amount of time considering nuclear pulse propulsion as a legitimate method of lofting spacecraft into orbit from the ground.

When you say Mun instead of Moon and look for Minmus in the sky.

...and exclaim "found it!" when you see Venus.
When you accidentally say that Europa is the second moon of Jool. Or that the planet with all the rings and Titan orbiting it is Sentar.

When you start making rocket drawings on school when the teacher decides to not go to work.

When you make rocket motors and rockets on The Powder Toy...

Both of those are haunting me now
When you draw maneuver orbit maps on your homework that the teacher puts little "?? please focus on your work" notes in red pen next to when you turn it in.

^ Oddly enough I did that BEFORE I started Kerballing. I must be insane.

...when you continue to make in-jokes about KSP to your friends despite the fact that none of them actually play the game.

...when you start KSP as soon as your computer turns on, only to realize you didn't actually want to play KSP.

...when you realize in horror that there actually is a point, far out in the abyss of infinity, where a human can play KSP long enough and frequently enough to actually experience the feeling of not wanting to play right now, and worse, that you've actually hit it.

...when you go to a game development competition and spend half of it playing KSP instead of developing anything.

...WHEN YOU HAVE KERBAL DREAMS D:
When you say pluto goes inside the orbit of Jupiter...
When you recognize parts of Curiosity rover.
When your car is too slow and you say, "Moar Boosters!"
When KSP has helped you get through various parts of an introduction to cosmology course.
when you build a rocket. a actual rocket. and die flying it.
When you get the Kerbal planets mixed up with the real planets (like calling Mars "Duna")
